message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: State-of-the-Art and Future Research Challenges in UAV Swarms
Paper Abstract: Due to their potential to accomplish complicated missions more effectively, UAV swarms have attracted a lot of attention lately. UAV swarm offers enhanced intelligence, improved coordination, increased flexibility, survivability, and reconfigurability. It is a multi-disciplinary system that necessitates a tight integration of several sub-systems, including optimal trajectory planning, localization, task coordination, etc. This review covers the important aspects of UAV swarms including swarm formation control, communication, swarm path planning, autonomy, coordination, and security. It additionally explores recent technical advancements in UAV swarm algorithms that have made the development of complex UAV swarm systems possible. This paper also provides insight into ethical aspects and the use cases of UAV swarms in various military, civilian, and entertainment applications. This paper is concluded by highlighting the potential future directions and challenges of UAV swarm technology and the need for more research and development to exploit their potential fully. Overall, this paper presents a comprehensive review of UAV swarm technology, addressing its potential for revolutionizing many fields and supporting advancements in the future.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

2. **Oil and Gas**: In the drilling industry, formation control relates to well control. Oil well control involves preventing the formation gas or fluid (hydrocarbons), usually referred to as a kick, from entering into the wellbore during drilling or well interventions.

The most prominent use appears to be in robotics, where formation control deals with coordinating multiple robotic systems to maintain a desired spatial arrangement or pattern. Web search results for query: "autonomous robot"

Links: [{"title":"Autonomous robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_robot"},{"title":"Autonomous robot architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_robot_architecture"},{"title":"Lethal autonomous weapon - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lethal_autonomous_weapon"},{"title":"Denning Mobile Robot Company - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_research_robot"},{"title":"Delivery robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delivery_robot"},{"title":"Energetically Autonomous Tactical Robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energetically_Autonomous_Tactical_Robot"},{"title":"Autonomous (novel) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_(novel)"},{"title":"Avride - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avride"},{"title":"List of robotics companies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_robotics_companies"},{"title":"Autonomous Robotics Ltd - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Robotics_Ltd"}]

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about autonomous robots:

## Definition and Overview

An autonomous robot is a robot that acts without recourse to human control.(no content)Historic examples include space probes, while modern examples include self-driving vacuums and cars.

## Common Applications

Autonomous robots are used in various settings:

- **Domestic use**: A new area showing commercial promise is domestic robots, with a flood of small vacuuming robots beginning with iRobot and Electrolux in 2002.

- **Delivery services**: A delivery robot is an autonomous robot that provides "last mile" delivery services.(no content)Delivery robots can be used in different settings such as food delivery, package delivery, hospital delivery, and room service.

- **Security and monitoring**: Amazon launched its Astro for home monitoring, security and eldercare in September 2021.

## Key Technologies

Autonomous robots must have a range of environmental sensors to perform their task and stay out of trouble.(no content)The most advanced systems now fuse information from various sensors for both localization (position) and navigation.

The search results show that autonomous robotics is a rapidly growing field with increasing applications across residential, commercial, and industrial sectors.

Web search results for query: "UAV unmanned aerial vehicle"

Links: [{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"Unmanned combat aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_combat_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"History of unmanned aerial vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicles"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicles"},{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicle programs of the Central Intelligence Agency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UAV_programs_of_the_CIA"},{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicles in the United States military - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicles_in_the_United_States_military"},{"title":"1st Center of the Unmanned Systems Forces - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/14th_Unmanned_Aerial_Vehicle_Regiment_(Ukraine)"},{"title":"UDS Partisan Recon - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UDS_Partisan_Recon"},{"title":"FP-1 (unmanned aerial vehicle)","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FP-1_(unmanned_aerial_vehicle)"},{"title":"Medium-altitude long-endurance UAV - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medium-altitude_long-endurance_UAV"}]

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about UAVs (Unmanned Aerial Vehicles):

## Definition

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.

## Key Characteristics

UAVs include both autonomous drones and remotely piloted vehicles, and are capable of controlled, sustained level flight powered by a jet, reciprocating, or electric engine.(no content)A UAV differs from a cruise missile in that a UAV is intended to be recovered after its mission, while a cruise missile impacts its target.

## History

The earliest recorded use of an unmanned aerial vehicle for warfighting occurred in July 1849, with a balloon carrier in the first offensive use of air power in naval aviation, when Austrian forces besieging Venice attempted to launch some 200 incendiary balloons at the besieged city.(no content)The earliest attempt at a powered UAV was A. M. Low's "Aerial Target" in 1916, with Geoffrey de Havilland's monoplane confirmed as the first to fly under control on 21 March 1917 using his radio system.

## Current Usage and Proliferation

By 2013 at least 50 countries used UAVs, with China, Iran, Israel, Pakistan, Turkey, and others designing and building their own varieties.(no content)In 2006, the US Federal Aviation Administration allowed the usage of unmanned aerial vehicles inside civilian airspace with specific regulations, and in 2013, DJI released the first model of the Phantom drone, priced at $629 as an entry-level option.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about UAVs (Unmanned Aerial Vehicles):

## Definition

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.

## Key Characteristics

UAVs include both autonomous drones and remotely piloted vehicles, and are capable of controlled, sustained level flight powered by a jet, reciprocating, or electric engine.(no content)A UAV differs from a cruise missile in that a UAV is intended to be recovered after its mission, while a cruise missile impacts its target.

## History

The earliest recorded use of an unmanned aerial vehicle for warfighting occurred in July 1849, with a balloon carrier in the first offensive use of air power in naval aviation, when Austrian forces besieging Venice attempted to launch some 200 incendiary balloons at the besieged city.(no content)The earliest attempt at a powered UAV was A. M. Low's "Aerial Target" in 1916, with Geoffrey de Havilland's monoplane confirmed as the first to fly under control on 21 March 1917 using his radio system.

## Current Usage and Proliferation

By 2013 at least 50 countries used UAVs, with China, Iran, Israel, Pakistan, Turkey, and others designing and building their own varieties.(no content)In 2006, the US Federal Aviation Administration allowed the usage of unmanned aerial vehicles inside civilian airspace with specific regulations, and in 2013, DJI released the first model of the Phantom drone, priced at $629 as an entry-level option.

I've completed the web search for "path planning robot". Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Overview

Real-time path planning is a term used in robotics that consists of motion planning methods that can adapt to real-time changes in the environment.

## Core Problem

A basic motion planning problem is to compute a continuous path that connects a start configuration and a goal configuration while avoiding collision with known obstacles.

## Key Algorithms and Approaches

The search results reveal several important path planning methods:

1. **Probabilistic Roadmap (PRM)**: The probabilistic roadmap planner is a motion planning algorithm in robotics which solves the problem of determining a path between a starting configuration of the robot and a goal configuration while avoiding collisions.

2. **Grid-Based Approaches**: At each grid point, the robot is allowed to move to adjacent grid points as long as the line between them is completely contained within free space, and search algorithms like A* are used to find a path from the start to the goal.

3. **Potential Field Methods**: The evolutionary artificial potential field method uses a mix of artificial repulsive and attractive forces in order to plan a path for the robot, with attractive forces originating from the target and repulsive forces coming from obstacles.

4. **Incremental Search (D* algorithms)**: Algorithms make assumptions about unknown terrain and find a shortest path under these assumptions, then when observing new map information, they add the information to the map and replan a new path if necessary.

## Applications

Motion planning has several robotics applications, such as autonomy, automation, and robot design in CAD software, as well as applications in other fields, such as animating digital characters, video games, and architectural design.

Links: [{"title":"Swarm robotic platforms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotic_platforms"},{"title":"Swarm robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotics"},{"title":"Ant robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ant_robotics"},{"title":"Swarm (novelette) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_(novelette)"},{"title":"Swarm intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_intelligence"},{"title":"Kilobot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kilobot"},{"title":"S-bot mobile robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S-bot_mobile_robot"},{"title":"Sabine Hauert - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sabine_Hauert"},{"title":"Gerardo Beni - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerardo_Beni"},{"title":"IISc Guidance, Control and Decision Systems Laboratory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_Robotics_Laboratory_at_IISc"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about swarm robotics:

## Overview

Swarm robotic platforms apply swarm robotics in multi-robot collaboration.(no content)Unlike distributed robotic systems in general, swarm robotics emphasizes a large number of robots.

## Key Characteristics

Robots are autonomous, can interact with the surroundings and give feedback to modify the environment, possess local perceiving and communicating capabilities such as wireless transmission systems, do not exploit centralized swarm control or global knowledge, and cooperate with each other to accomplish the given task.

## Inspiration

Swarm robotics takes inspiration from nature such as collective problemsolving mechanisms seen in nature like honey bee aggregation.

## History

The phrase "swarm robotics" was reported to make its first appearance in 1991 according to Google Scholar, but research regarding swarm robotics began to grow in early 2000s.(no content)One of the first international projects regarding swarm robotics was the SWARM-BOTS project funded by the European Commission between 2001 and 2005, in which a swarm of up to 20 of robots capable of independently physically connect to each other to form a cooperating system were used to study swarm behaviors such as collective transport, area coverage, and searching for objects.

## Applications

A promising use of swarm robotics is in search and rescue missions. Swarms of robots of different sizes could be sent to places that rescue-workers cannot reach safely, to explore the unknown environment and solve complex mazes via onboard sensors.(no content)Swarm robotics can also be suited to tasks that demand cheap designs, for instance mining or agricultural shepherding tasks.

Web search results for query: "localization robotics"

Links: [{"title":"Robot navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_navigation"},{"title":"Simultaneous localization and mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simultaneous_localization_and_mapping"},{"title":"Robotic mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotic_mapping"},{"title":"Monte Carlo localization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monte_Carlo_localization"},{"title":"Autonomous robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_robot"},{"title":"Mobile robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_robot"},{"title":"Gregory Dudek - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gregory_Dudek"},{"title":"Human–robot interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human–robot_interaction"},{"title":"Neurorobotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neurorobotics"},{"title":"Robot Operating System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_Operating_System"}]

I've found comprehensive information about localization in robotics. Here's what the search reveals:

## Overview

Robot localization denotes the robot's ability to establish its own position and orientation within the frame of reference.(no content)Localization is calculated by one or more means, using sensors such motor encoders, vision, Stereopsis, lasers and global positioning systems.

## Key Approaches

**SLAM (Simultaneous Localization and Mapping)**

Simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM) is the computational problem of constructing or updating a map of an unknown environment while simultaneously keeping track of an agent's location within it.(no content)Popular approximate solution methods include the particle filter, extended Kalman filter, covariance intersection, and GraphSLAM.

**Monte Carlo Localization**

Monte Carlo localization (MCL), also known as particle filter localization, is an algorithm for robots to localize using a particle filter. Given a map of the environment, the algorithm estimates the position and orientation of a robot as it moves and senses the environment.

## Information Sources for Localization

Robots use two main types of information:

1. Dead reckoning methods such as tracking the number of revolutions of its wheels, which corresponds to the idiothetic source and can give the absolute position of the robot, but is subject to cumulative error.

2. The allothetic source corresponds to the sensors of the robot, like a camera, a microphone, laser, lidar, or sonar.

## Applications

SLAM algorithms are used in robot navigation, robotic mapping and odometry for virtual reality or augmented reality.(no content)Published approaches are employed in self-driving cars, unmanned aerial vehicles, autonomous underwater vehicles, planetary rovers, newer domestic robots and even inside the human body.

I've found comprehensive information about localization in robotics. Here's what the search reveals:

## Overview

Robot localization denotes the robot's ability to establish its own position and orientation within the frame of reference.(no content)Localization is calculated by one or more means, using sensors such motor encoders, vision, Stereopsis, lasers and global positioning systems.

## Key Approaches

**SLAM (Simultaneous Localization and Mapping)**

Simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM) is the computational problem of constructing or updating a map of an unknown environment while simultaneously keeping track of an agent's location within it.(no content)Popular approximate solution methods include the particle filter, extended Kalman filter, covariance intersection, and GraphSLAM.

**Monte Carlo Localization**

Monte Carlo localization (MCL), also known as particle filter localization, is an algorithm for robots to localize using a particle filter. Given a map of the environment, the algorithm estimates the position and orientation of a robot as it moves and senses the environment.

## Information Sources for Localization

Robots use two main types of information:

1. Dead reckoning methods such as tracking the number of revolutions of its wheels, which corresponds to the idiothetic source and can give the absolute position of the robot, but is subject to cumulative error.

2. The allothetic source corresponds to the sensors of the robot, like a camera, a microphone, laser, lidar, or sonar.

## Applications

SLAM algorithms are used in robot navigation, robotic mapping and odometry for virtual reality or augmented reality.(no content)Published approaches are employed in self-driving cars, unmanned aerial vehicles, autonomous underwater vehicles, planetary rovers, newer domestic robots and even inside the human body.

## Search Results: Coordinated Control Systems

Based on the web search, here's what I found about coordinated control systems:

### Key Concepts

Agents in decentralized control systems can interact using communication channels and coordinate their actions. This is fundamental to how coordinated control systems operate.

### Motion Control Applications

In the context of motion control, the interface between the motion controller and drives it control is very critical when coordinated motion is required, as it must provide tight synchronization.(no content)Open interfaces were developed that satisfied the requirements of coordinated motion control, the first being SERCOS in 1991 which is now enhanced to SERCOS III.

### Traffic Control Example

One practical application is in traffic management. Coordinated (progressed) systems are controlled from a master controller and are set up so lights "cascade" (progress) in sequence so platoons of vehicles can proceed through a continuous series of green lights.

### Collaborative Control Theory

More broadly, Collaborative Control Theory (CCT) is a collection of principles and models for supporting the effective design of collaborative e-Work systems. Beyond human collaboration, advances in information and communications technologies, artificial intelligence, multi-agent systems, and cyber physical systems have enabled cyber-supported collaboration in highly distributed organizations of people, robots, and autonomous systems.

Coordinated control systems are used across numerous industries including manufacturing, traffic management, robotics, and distributed processes where multiple controllers or agents need to work together in a synchronized manner.

Here are the search results for "cybersecurity robots":

## Security and Autonomous Robots

Knightscope robots are fully autonomous using self-driving technology and are designed to alert police and security of incidents through sensors that detect weapons, read license plates and detect other suspicious activities.(no content)Knightscope is the most well known maker of fully autonomous security robots.(no content)Users of Knightscope robots have generally reported lower crime rates in the areas the robots were deployed, attributed mostly to physical deterrence by the robot's presence.(no content)Robot features include the ability to read license plates, run thermal scans, detect hidden weapons, and identify the faces of wanted people.

## Other Security Robot Applications

Security robots can be programmed to detect intruders and respond in a particular way depending upon where the intruder is. For example, Amazon launched its Astro for home monitoring, security and eldercare in September 2021.

## Cybersecurity Concerns with Robotic Systems

The search results also highlight cybersecurity concerns: Robotic systems are controlled by PLCs, and a cyberattack that targets them can have immediate and dire consequences. Additionally, cybersecurity experts have raised concerns about the rising number of bots online, which now make up a large portion of internet traffic.

I've completed the web search for "wireless communication networks." Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Overview

Wireless communication systems are systems that use wireless 'over the air' technologies to create a telecommunications channel between two points.

## Types of Wireless Networks

Examples of wireless networks include cell phone networks, wireless local area networks (WLANs), wireless sensor networks, satellite communication networks, and terrestrial microwave networks.

## Major Technologies

**Cellular Networks:** A cellular network or mobile network is a radio network distributed over land areas called cells, each served by at least one fixed-location transceiver, known as a cell site or base station. In a cellular network, each cell characteristically uses a different set of radio frequencies from all their immediate neighbouring cells to avoid any interference. When joined these cells provide radio coverage over a wide geographic area.

**Wi-Fi:** A wireless LAN (WLAN) is a wireless computer network that links two or more devices using wireless communication to form a local area network (LAN) within a limited area such as a home, school, computer laboratory, campus, or office building. This gives users the ability to move around within the area and remain connected to the network.

**Wireless Sensor Networks:** Wireless Sensor Networks (WSN / WSAN) are, generically, networks of low-power, low-cost devices that interconnect wirelessly to collect, exchange, and sometimes act-on data collected from their physical environments.

## Communication Methods

Wireless networks use electromagnetic waves to transmit data through the air, enabling devices to connect and communicate without physical cables.

I've completed the web search for "wireless communication networks." Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Overview

Wireless communication systems are systems that use wireless 'over the air' technologies to create a telecommunications channel between two points.

## Types of Wireless Networks

Examples of wireless networks include cell phone networks, wireless local area networks (WLANs), wireless sensor networks, satellite communication networks, and terrestrial microwave networks.

## Major Technologies

**Cellular Networks:** A cellular network or mobile network is a radio network distributed over land areas called cells, each served by at least one fixed-location transceiver, known as a cell site or base station. In a cellular network, each cell characteristically uses a different set of radio frequencies from all their immediate neighbouring cells to avoid any interference. When joined these cells provide radio coverage over a wide geographic area.

**Wi-Fi:** A wireless LAN (WLAN) is a wireless computer network that links two or more devices using wireless communication to form a local area network (LAN) within a limited area such as a home, school, computer laboratory, campus, or office building. This gives users the ability to move around within the area and remain connected to the network.

**Wireless Sensor Networks:** Wireless Sensor Networks (WSN / WSAN) are, generically, networks of low-power, low-cost devices that interconnect wirelessly to collect, exchange, and sometimes act-on data collected from their physical environments.

## Communication Methods

Wireless networks use electromagnetic waves to transmit data through the air, enabling devices to connect and communicate without physical cables.

Web search results for query: "trajectory planning robotics"

Links: [{"title":"Motion planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_planning"},{"title":"Real-time path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_path_planning"},{"title":"Trajectory optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trajectory_optimization"},{"title":"Kinodynamic planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kinodynamic_planning"},{"title":"Motion control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_control"},{"title":"Probabilistic roadmap - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probabilistic_roadmap"},{"title":"Any-angle path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Block_A*"},{"title":"Robot navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_navigation"},{"title":"Automated planning and scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_planning_and_scheduling"},{"title":"OMPL - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ompl"}]

I've completed the web search for "trajectory planning robotics." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Trajectory optimization has a wide variety of applications, primarily in robotics: industry, manipulation, walking, path-planning, and aerospace.

## Key Concepts

**Motion Planning Foundation**: A basic motion planning problem is to compute a continuous path that connects a start configuration S and a goal configuration G, while avoiding collision with known obstacles.

**Kinodynamic Planning**: In robotics and motion planning, kinodynamic planning is a class of problems for which velocity, acceleration, and force/torque bounds must be satisfied, together with kinematic constraints such as avoiding obstacles.

## Applications

A robotic arm with 7 joints and 7 links (7-DOF) is a redundant system where one cartesian position of an end-effector can correspond to an infinite number of joint angle positions, thus this redundancy can be used to optimize a trajectory to, for example, avoid any obstacles in the workspace or minimize the torque in the joints.(no content)Trajectory optimization is often used to compute trajectories for quadrotor helicopters.

## Planning Methods

Sampling-based algorithms are currently considered state-of-the-art for motion planning in high-dimensional spaces, and have been applied to problems which have dozens or even hundreds of dimensions (robotic manipulators, biological molecules, animated digital characters, and legged robots).

The search results provide comprehensive information about trajectory planning approaches, algorithms, and their applications across different robotics domains.

Web search results for query: "task allocation scheduling"

Links: [{"title":"Scheduling (computing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scheduling_(computing)"},{"title":"Optimal job scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_job_scheduling"},{"title":"Job-shop scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Job-shop_scheduling"},{"title":"Parallel task scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parallel_task_scheduling"},{"title":"Completely Fair Scheduler - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Completely_Fair_Scheduler"},{"title":"Interval scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interval_scheduling"},{"title":"Scheduling (production processes) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scheduling_(production_processes)"},{"title":"Identical-machines scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Identical-machines_scheduling"},{"title":"Stochastic scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_scheduling"},{"title":"Windows Task Scheduler - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_Task_Scheduler"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of task allocation scheduling:

## Overview

Scheduling deals with the problem of deciding which of the outstanding requests is to be allocated resources.(no content)The main purposes of scheduling algorithms are to minimize resource starvation and to ensure fairness amongst the parties utilizing the resources.

## Key Types

**In Computing:**
- First in, first out (FIFO), also known as first come, first served (FCFS), is the simplest scheduling algorithm, which simply queues processes in the order that they arrive in the ready queue, and is commonly used for a task queue.

**In Production/Manufacturing:**
Scheduling is the process of arranging, controlling and optimizing work and workloads in a production process, and companies use backward and forward scheduling to allocate plant and machinery resources, plan human resources, plan production processes and purchase materials.

## Common Scheduling Problems

Several important variants exist:

- **Job-shop scheduling:** Job-shop scheduling is an optimization problem in computer science and operations research and is a variant of optimal job scheduling.

- **Interval scheduling:** Interval scheduling is a class of problems in computer science, particularly in the area of algorithm design, which considers a set of tasks where each task is represented by an interval describing the time in which it needs to be processed by some machine or resource.

- **Identical-machines scheduling:** Identical-machines scheduling is an optimization problem in computer science and operations research where we are given n jobs of varying processing times, which need to be scheduled on m identical machines, such that a certain objective function is optimized, for example, the makespan is minimized.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name (Wikipedia article title), relation (uses or proposes), entity_type (task/method/data/artifact/tool/concept/other), wikipedia_url (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance (1 sentence)

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Perfect! All tasks have been completed successfully. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

I've successfully analyzed the UAV Swarms paper and generated the triples output file. Here are the key results:

### Paper Classification
- **Type**: **Survey** - This is a literature review and overview paper covering existing work on UAV swarms rather than proposing novel methods.

### Triples Generated: 10 entities

The paper references and builds upon these existing technologies and concepts:

1. **Unmanned aerial vehicle** (Tool) - The core subject matter
2. **Swarm robotics** (Concept) - Multi-robot coordination principles
3. **Control theory** (Concept) - Formation and coordinated control
4. **Motion planning** (Method) - Path and trajectory planning
5. **Robot navigation** (Method) - Localization and autonomous movement
6. **Autonomous robot** (Concept) - Autonomy in UAV operations
7. **Wireless network** (Tool) - Communication infrastructure
8. **Scheduling (computing)** (Method) - Task allocation and coordination
9. **Control system** (Concept) - Multi-agent behavior management
10. **Control system security** (Concept) - Security for autonomous systems

### Validation Results
✅ All validation checks passed:
- Paper type correctly classified as "survey"
